title: Protocol for combining immunological procedures with cell cycle stage synchronization to detect cell-cycle-specific complexes
procedures:
Step-by-step method details
Step-by-step method details
Part 1. Cell cycle synchronization
Timing: 4 days
In this step, culture cells are synchronized at G1/S boundary or mitosis and go through cell cycle stages synchronously. The step helps monitor the S phase and mitotic stages because the cell numbers of the S phase and mitotic cells are lower than those in other cell-cycle stages.1[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib1],2[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib2]
Double-thymidine synchronization for G1/S stage.
Seed HeLa cells at 2 × 106 cells /10 cm dish for each time point.
Note: According to sample numbers, culture is scaled up. For each time point, seed two 10 cm dishes with 2 × 106 HeLa cells for extraction.
Note: Ensure uniform distribution across the culture dish. The aggregation of the cells would inhibit the growth, resulting in poor synchronization.
Allow the cells to grow for 16 h from the seeded time point and replace the media with supplemented DMEM media containing thymidine, which can arrest the cell at G1/S boundary by inhibiting DNA synthesis.
After treatment with thymidine for 16 h, wash the cells twice with 10 mL of drug-free supplemented DMEM media prewarmed at 37°C.
Culture the cells in drug-free supplemented DMEM media for 10 h.
After 10 h, replace the media with supplemented DMEM media containing thymidine and allow the cells to grow under the thymidine-containing media for 16 h.
After 16 h, wash the drug-treated cells twice with 10 mL of drug-free supplemented DMEM media prewarmed at 37°C and cultured under drug-free supplemented DMEM media. Cells are harvested at the selected time points (ex. 3, 6,9,12, 15, 18 h).
Note: To confirm cell cycle status, prepare a FACS sample at 4 × 105 cells /6 cm dish per time point.
Troubleshooting 1[href=https://www.wicell.org#sec6.1].
Thymidine and nocodazole block for synchronization in mitosis.

Seed HeLa cells at 2 × 106 cells /10 cm dish for each time point.
Note: According to sample numbers, culture is scaled up. For each time point, seed two 10 cm dishes with 2 × 106 HeLa cells for extraction.
Note: Ensure uniform distribution across the culture dish. The aggregation of the cells would inhibit the growth, resulting in poor synchronization.
Allow the cells to grow for 16 h from the seeded time point and replace the media with supplemented DMEM media containing thymidine.
After treatment with thymidine for 16 h, wash the cells twice with 10 mL of drug-free supplemented DMEM media prewarmed at 37°C.
Culture the cells in drug-free supplemented DMEM media for 6 h.
After 6 h, replace the media with supplemented DMEM media containing nocodazole to block mitotic progression by depolymerizing microtubules, and treat the cells with nocodazole for 6 h. Collect the cells arrested in mitosis at time zero.
Wash the cells twice with 10 mL of drug-free supplemented DMEM media prewarmed at 37°C. Culture the cells in drug-free supplemented DMEM media. Harvest the cells at selected time points (ex. 10, 20, 30, 40, 50, and 60 min).
Note: To confirm cell cycle status, prepare a FACS sample at 4 × 105 cells /6 cm dish per time point [troubleshooting 1[href=https://www.wicell.org#sec6.1]].
Part 2. Preparation of cell extracts
Timing: 1 h, days
In this step, prepare the cell extracts from synchronized cells at each time point. The cell extract at each time point should be extracted immediately after cell collection to avoid the degradation of protein and the breakage of protein complexes by freezing.
Remove the media by decantation, dislodge the cells directly by scraping, and transfer the cells and media (∼1 mL) into 1.5 mL tubes.

Spin down the cells at 80 × g for 5 min at room temperature and wash the cells twice with 500 μL of PBS. Add 500 μL of ice-cold NP-40 lysis buffer (per 2 × 10 cm dishes) and suspend the cells by pipetting 10 times. Incubate on ice for 20 min.
Mix the suspension with a Vortex mixer for 15 s at full speed to disrupt viscous materials. Alternatively, carry out benzonase treatment, sonication, or homogenization on the lysates to break the DNA. Centrifuge the cell extracts at 10,000 × g for 20 min at 4°C. Transfer the supernatant to clean tubes.
Measure the protein concentration of the supernatant using a standard Bradford protein assay.
Note: ∼7 mg of protein is obtained from two 10 cm dishes of HeLa cells.
Pause point: No pause points in this step.
Part 3. Preparation of stepwise glycerol gradient for fractionation of protein complex by size
Timing: 2 days
In this step, make the stepwise gradient for centrifugation and fractionate the sample after centrifugation. The making gradient and fractionation of the sample are critical for size fractionation.
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/2391-Fig1.jpg
Figure 1. Glycerol gradient centrifugation
(A) 800 μL of the highest glycerol concentration in NP-40 lysis buffer is first layered in the bottom of a 5 mL tube. Stepwise, 800 μL of each glycerol concentration in NP-40 lysis buffer is overlayed gently on the previous layer. After standing for 1 h at 4°C, the boundary of gradients is diffused and becomes invisible.
(B) After centrifugation, the gradient is fractionated from top to bottom using a micropipette. The pipet is positioned at the tube’s center and brings the tip of the pipette-tip vertically near the liquid surface. The surface is swelled by surface tension (arrowhead). Maintain the immersion depth and aspirate the sample carefully.
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/2391-Fig2.jpg

Figure 2. Electrophoresis analysis of marker proteins by 18%–40% glycerol gradient centrifugation
(A) Electrophoresis of the indicated fractions from 18%–40% glycerol gradient centrifugation and Coomassie Brilliant Blue staining. The sample containing BSA, Aldolase (Ald), Catalase (Cat), and Thyroglobulin (TG) was fractionated and analyzed by 7.5% SDS-PAGE.
(B) Calculation analysis of standard protein migration from the fractionation. The peak fractions of each protein and the molecular weight were plotted. The coefficient of determination (R2) was calculated from independent 2 experiments, including (A).
Make glycerol gradient.
Choose a rotor and tube type depending on the volume of cell lysate.
For SW 40 rotor, 14 mL of Open-Top Thinwall polypropylene Tubes (344060) are used.
For SW 55 Ti rotor, 5 mL of Open-Top Thinwall polypropylene Tubes (326819) are used.
For STL 500 rotor, 2.2 mL of Open-Top Thinwall polypropylene Tubes (347357) are used.
Using each tube, fill 9/10 volume of tube size with the solution of the sample plus glycerol cushion.
Note: For example, using SW 55 Ti rotor, apply 0.5 mL of cell extract plus 4 mL of glycerol gradient cushion into a 5 mL tube.
800 μL of the highest glycerol concentration in NP-40 lysis buffer is first layered in the bottom of a 5 mL tube. Stepwise, 800 μL of each glycerol concentration in NP-40 lysis buffer is overlayed softly and gently on the previous layer (Figure 1[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig1]A).
Note: The continuous gradient maker can be used. Gradient former (Gradient Master 107, BioComp Instruments).
Keep the tube for 1 h at 4°C. After 1 h, the boundary of gradients is diffused and becomes invisible (Figure 1[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig1]A). Troubleshooting 2[href=https://www.wicell.org#sec6.3].
Centrifuge and fractionate.
Layer 0.5–2 mg of cell extracts (1–4 μg/mL protein concentration) on the glycerol cushion (max volume of 500 μL).

Note: Using SW 55 Ti rotor, up to 1 mg of cell extracts is used for the best result. The sample volume is a maximum of up to 1/10 volume of tube size.
Ultracentrifuge at 30,000 × g for 18 h at 4°C.
Note: Set the acceleration and deceleration to a minimum.
After centrifugation, fractionate the gradient from top to bottom using a micropipette with surface tension (Figure 1[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig1]B). Each fraction volume is 200 μL.
Add an equal amount of ice-cold TCA solution to 20 μL of each fraction to precipitate proteins and mix with a Vortex mixer for 15 s at full speed. Incubate the mixture on ice for 30 min and centrifuge for 10 min at 12,000 × g at 4°C.
Discard the supernatant, rinse the pellet fraction with ice-cold ethanol, and centrifuge for 5 min at 12,000 × g at 4°C. Dry the pellet and resuspend it into 50 μL of 1 × SDS sample buffer. 1/10 volume of each sample will be subjected to SDS-PAGE and western blotting analysis.
Note: For estimation of the mass of the protein complex, prepare sedimentation markers with the same concentration of glycerol gradient conditions (Figure 2[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig2]). A sedimentation markers: 4.2S Bovine serum albumin (66 kDa), 8.9S beta-amylase (200 kDa), 17.6S apoferritin (443 kDa), 19S Thyroglobulin (670 kDa).
Pause point: No pause points in this step. After step 8e, the samples for western blotting can be stored at −20°C, but the samples for immunoprecipitation cannot be stored.
Troubleshooting 2[href=https://www.wicell.org#sec6.3] and 3[href=https://www.wicell.org#sec6.5].
Part 4. Preparation of immunoprecipitation
Timing: 2 days
In this step, perform immunoprecipitation using fractions after glycerol gradient centrifugation.
Immunoprecipitation.
180 μL of each fraction is subjected to co-immunoprecipitation with the specific antibody.

Add 0.5 μg of the antibody to the 180 μL of each fraction and an equal amount of ice-cold NP-40 lysis buffer. Rotate the tubes gently at 4°C overnight.
Next day (∼16 h), add 40 μL of protein G- Sepharose beads (50% suspension) to each tube and rotate each tube gently at 4°C for 6 h.
Wash protein G- Sepharose bead once with 500 μL of NP-40 lysis buffer and twice with 500 μL of NP-40 lysis buffer without NaCl.
Remove the wash buffer completely and add 40 μL of 2 × SDS sample buffer into each tube.
Mix by gentle Vortex mixing and boil at 95°C for 6 min.
Mix the boiled samples with high-speed Vortex mixing for 15 s and spun down immediately. The immunoprecipitants are subjected to SDS-PAGE and western blotting analysis.
Pause point: After step 9g, the samples can be stored at −20°C for several months.
Part 5. Immunofluorescence experiment using double-thymidine synchronization for G1/S stage
Timing: 6 days
In this step, perform immunofluorescence using double-thymidine synchronization for G1/S stage. Using this protocol, G2 and mitotic cells are easily observed and determined by the cell cycle stage-specific colocalization during these phases.2[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib2],3[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib3]
Preparation of poly-lysine coated coverslips.
Coat acid-washed coverslips in bulk with 10–15 mL of 1 mg/mL PLL in ddH20 in a petri dish. Rock for at least 30 min at room temperature or overnight at 4°C.
Note: Use high MW poly-L-lysine (greater than 300K) for best results.
Wash coverslips in ddH20 at least 10 times.
Note: free polyaminoacids are cytotoxic for culture cells.
Rinse coverslips in 100% ethanol twice in a sterile hood.
Store in 70% ethanol for several months.
Cell cycle synchronization and Immunofluorescence experiments.

Place the poly-L-Lysine coated coverslips in 10 cm dishes. After ethanol sterilization, seed HeLa cells at 2 × 106 cells /10 cm dish per time point.
Grow the cells for 16 h from the seeded time point and replace the media with supplemented DMEM media containing thymidine.
Treat the cells with thymidine for 16 h, and wash the drug-treated cells twice with 10 mL of drug-free supplemented DMEM media prewarmed at 37°C. Culture the cells in drug-free supplemented DMEM media for 10 h.
After 10 h, replace the media with supplemented DMEM media containing thymidine, and treat the cells with thymidine for 16 h.
After 16 h, wash the drug-treated cells with 10 mL of drug-free supplemented DMEM media prewarmed at 37°C twice and culture under drug-free supplemented DMEM media.
After 6 h from thymidine release, collect the cells on coverslips at selected time points and place in 6 wells plates.
The cells in G2 and mitosis are observed around 8 h from thymidine release.
To obtain the cells progressing mitosis, collect samples every 20 min after 8 h.
Wash the samples with PHEM buffer twice, and permeabilize the cells with PHEM containing 0.2% Triton X-100 for 2 min on ice. Fix the cells with 4% paraformaldehyde in PHEM for 20 min on ice.
Note: The temperature for these treatments is dependent on the antigen.
Wash the cells twice with ice-cold PBS for 5 min on ice, and perform the blocking step with boiled donkey serum.
Note: The temperature is dependent on the antigen.
Incubate each sample with 1st antibodies (anti-Mad2, Dynein Antibody, 74 kDa Intermediate chains, cytoplasmic, clone 74.1, 70.1, and Anti-β-Tubulin−Cy3 antibodies) at 4°C overnight and wash three times with TBST buffer for 5 min at room temperature.

Incubate each sample with 2nd antibody (anti-mouse or rabbit IgG (H+L) conjugated Alexa Flour 488) at 4°C for 6 h and wash three times with TBST buffer for 5 min at room temperature.
Stain the cells with 50 ng/mL Hoechst 33342 solution for 10 min at room temperature. Mount the samples with SlowFad Gold Antifade Mountant.
Observe the samples under fluorescence microscopy. Troubleshooting 4[href=https://www.wicell.org#sec6.7] and 5[href=https://www.wicell.org#sec6.9].
Pause point: After step 10d, coated coverslips can be stored at room temperature for several months.
